title: Transport Layer
description: Understanding TCP, UDP, and transport layer protocols

keyConcepts.title: Transport Layer Functions
keyConcepts.description: Provides end-to-end communication, error recovery, flow control, and multiplexing through port numbers.

keyConcepts.title: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol)
keyConcepts.description: Connection-oriented, reliable protocol with 3-way handshake, sequencing, acknowledgments, and flow control.

keyConcepts.title: UDP (User Datagram Protocol)
keyConcepts.description: Connectionless, best-effort delivery protocol. Fast but unreliable - no handshake, no acknowledgments.

keyConcepts.title: Port Numbers
keyConcepts.description: Identify specific applications. Well-known (0-1023), Registered (1024-49151), Dynamic (49152-65535).

keyConcepts.title: Socket
keyConcepts.description: Combination of IP address and port number that uniquely identifies a communication endpoint.

importantPoints: TCP uses a 3-way handshake: SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK
TCP termination uses a 4-way handshake: FIN , ACK, FIN, ACK
UDP header is 8 bytes (Source Port, Dest Port, Length, Checksum)
TCP provides flow control through window sizing
Sequence numbers allow TCP to reassemble segments in correct order
Well-known ports: HTTP=80, HTTPS=443, FTP=21, SSH=22, Telnet=23, DNS=53, DHCP=67/68
TCP is used when reliability is required (HTTP, FTP, SMTP)
UDP is used when speed is priority (DNS, DHCP, TFTP, streaming)
